title: A Watermark for Large Language Models

last_post.content: https://arxiv.org/abs/2301.10226

Ok, I am *really* impressed with this paper: https://arxiv.org/abs/2302.05116 "Example-Based Sampling with Diffusion Models"

Generating blue-noise-like sampling points through diffusion? Sure, neat, but I have seen it done before.

But remapping random point sets to grids (from jitter grid, or through Optimal Transport) to run convolutional networks on them is super smart.

The big announcement!!! The dsl.design book is officially out from Springer. You can now order it at the source or download it if you have a subscription: https://link.springer.com/book/10.1007/978-3-031-23669-3

The book aims at university teaching of language design and technology, with lots of small examples and exercises. Supported by a code repository.

BTW. We are not getting any money when you download, but please go ahead and download!!! :D

last_post.content: Looking forward to read https://ieeexplore.ieee.org/document/5471106 and https://arxiv.org/abs/2007.04725
Looking forward to read https://ieeexplore.ieee.org/document/5471106 and https://arxiv.org/abs/2007.04725

I started reading papers on arXiv.org because I enjoyed learning about generative machine learning models. Then I started boosting papers that I liked because I thought it might be helpful to others …

Now, I sometimes get people asking me to explain the paper to them because they can’t be bothered to read it 😛 What do you do in such a situation?

Would explaining the paper actually do any good? If they can’t be bothered to read the paper, are they going to bother reading my explanation? Is it worthwhile spending the time to explain something to such a person?

I don’t know … It feels as if it’s just a drive-by thing — either because they think it’s funny or because people are like that. Or are there people who are really like “I can’t be bothered to read a paper but if somebody gives me bite-sized info, I’ll take it”?

I think people confuse me 😀

title: Europe’s first humans hunted with bows and arrows

last_post.content:
It seems that Europe's first humans didn't hunt with spears, but with bows and arrows. In the same cave that contains what is believed to be the earliest evidence of humans in Europe, hundreds of arrow heads have been discovered.

This dates the history of #archery, my favourite pastime ever forever, as being at least 54,000 years old.

The lingering mystery, then, is why Neanderthals never picked up a bow.

Following a trail from John Naughton’s article about the fediverse restoring human communication, I read his previous article on ChatGPT, and that took me to Murray Shanahan on human language, and LLM models as predictive sequences of words designed to seem likely.

“Sequences of words with a propositional form are not special to the model itself in the way they are to us. The model itself has no notion of truth or falsehood, properly speaking, because it lacks the means to exercise these concepts in anything like the way we do.”

This is helping me to understand my feeling that what is at stake here is compositional language that is special to us. It matters, for this profound reason.

title: Extracting Training Data from Diffusion Models

last_post.content:
This time Google does the right thing - while shareholders grill them over "competition" with ChatGPT (not really...), they research and publish how useful and privacy preserving large models are.

It turns out, as suspected, they are not very useful for actual professional writers who understand "something" about writing: https://arxiv.org/abs/2211.05030

...and leak the dataset/private data, 2x worse with diffusion than GANs: https://arxiv.org/abs/2301.13188

No wonder Google is hesitant to use them. :)

'Learning-Rate-Free Learning by D-Adaptation'
- Aaron Defazio, Konstantin Mishchenko

The informational complexity of optimising convex, Lipschitz functions depends on the distance of the initial state to the true minimiser, which is typically unknown in practice. This work presents an adaptive scheme for estimating this distance, and shows that the resulting algorithm is then essentially rate-optimal, up to log factors.

We introduce a self-learning algorithm for synthesizing programs for OEIS sequences. (...)
